slides.txt: Handling and Preventing Workplace Violence & Harassment for Employees
Introduction
The purpose of this training is to raise awareness of actions and situations that could contribute to workplace violence and harassment.
The objective of this training is to make the participants aware of the laws, regulations and the organization's policies to handle workplace violence and harassment.
This training does not address all possible situations or conditions and is not intended to be a substitute for seeking help from a legal and/or human resources professionals when required.
If you have any questions or issues regarding workplace violence or harassment, please contact your manager or human resources.
What is Workplace Violence?
Workplace violence is defined as:
The exercise of physical force by a person against a worker, in a workplace, that causes or could cause physical injury to the worker.
It also includes: an attempt to exercise physical force against a worker, in a workplace, that could cause physical injury to the worker.
And: a statement or behaviour that is reasonable for a worker to interpret as a threat to exercise physical force against the worker, in a workplace, that could cause physical injury to the worker.
Examples of Conduct which may be considered Workplace Violence
Examples of conduct which may be considered workplace violence include, but are not limited to, the following:
Intimidating behaviour and/or physical contact that is threatening or aggressive.
Threatening an individual, his/her family or associates with physical harm.
The intentional destruction of company property or threat of destruction.
Harassing or threatening communications; stalking.
What is Workplace Harassment?
Workplace harassment is defined as:
Engaging in a course of vexatious comment or conduct against a worker in a workplace that is known or ought reasonably to be known to be unwelcome.
Examples of Workplace Harassment
Harassment in the workplace includes, but is not limited to:
Unwelcome sexual flirtations, advances, or propositions.
Verbal abuse of a sexual, racial, ethnic, religious, or other nature.
Verbal abuse about physical or mental limitations.
Graphic verbal comments about an individuals body.
Sexually degrading words used to describe an individual.
The display in the workplace of sexually suggestive objects or pictures, or other material derogatory to racial, ethnic or religious groups, etc.
Unwelcome or unwanted conduct based on individual sexual orientation.
What is not Harassment?

Any reasonable conduct or action that is considered to be part of a manager's or supervisor's work function that produces an unpleasant consequence for an employee is not considered to be workplace harassment.
Examples of such actions or conduct are:
Disciplinary actions; job assessment and evaluation; implementation of dress codes; changes in work schedules and assignments; workplace inspections.
Handling Workplace Violence Incidents
Using judgement in determining a potentially violent situation is critical and if it is determined that a threat is immediate:
Call emergency response contacts; security, foreman's office, safety specialist, HES team leader
Report as much information as possible (if you are in a position to explain your situation) including:
Your name, your location (building, floor, office, room, etc.), what is/has happened, if anyone is injured, nature of assistance required.
Emergency reponse contact will immediately contact the police and any other appropriate emergency services, such as ambulance or fire department (7-911).
Human resources and senior management must then be immediately contacted and informed of the situation.
Responding to Violence
The following are recommended ways to deal with a person who is threatening you:
Always remain calm; if you are going to signal for help, do so quietly.
Maintain eye contact with the person.
Do not risk the possibility of harm for yourself or others, do not try to grab the weapon.
Follow all instructions from the person who is threatening you.
Escape to a safe location only if you can do so without risk.
An individual may become violent unintentionally because of medical conditions.
Handling Workplace Harassment Incident
It is important to address harassment issues immediately.
Inform the person who is harassing to stop the behaviour immediately.
If it is not possible to inform the person or if the person does not stop the behaviour, contact human resources immediately.
Sources of Violence and Harassment
The key to preventing violence and harassment is to understand all potential sources of workplace violence and harassment.
Workplace violence and harassment can come from the following sources:
Employees: workers, managers and upservisors who work for the organization.
Domestic relationships: domestic relationships are persons who have or have had a personal relationship outside of work with an employee.
Domestic relationships include current or former spouse, relative, friend or an acquaintance.
Customers: customers are people who regularly conduct business with the organization. customers can be clients, patients, shoppers, etc.
External staff: external staff are employees of another organization who are required to conduct legitimate business with the organization.
Examples of external staff are contractors, consultants, couriers, etc.
Outsiders: outsiders are individuals who have no legitimate business with the organization.
Managers must know and understand the company policies and procedures in dealing with and preventing violence and harassment from any of the sources.
Workplace Domestic Violence
Domestic violence occuring in an employee's home may also enter into the workplace.
Workplace domestic violence is the situation where a person who has a personal relationship with an employee, such as: a current or former spouse, partner or, family member.
may physically harm, threaten or harass that employee at work.
If you witness a cluster of the following warning signs in the workplace, you can reasonably suspect domestic abuse:
Bruises and other signs of impact on the skin, with the excuse of 'accidents'.
Depression, crying; frequent and sudden absences; frequent lateness.
Frequent harassing phone calls to the person while they are at work.
Fear of the partner, references to the partner's anger.
Decreased productivity and attentiveness; isolation from friends and family; insufficient finances (money, credit cards, car).
If you witness some of these signs, it is reasonable to suspect domestic violence abuse.
Please contact your manager, supervisor or human resources.
If the manager or supervisor witnesses some of these signs, it is reasonable to suspect domestic abuse.
Managers and supervisors must contact human resources immediately and keep matters confidential.
Managers should not discuss their suspicions with other employees, however, they may inquire about the employee's behaviour at work to confirm their suspicion of domestic violence.
Managers and supervisors must maintain discretion and respect the privacy of the person at all times.
The company has policies and procedures to help employees who are victims of domestic violence.
Work Refusals Involving Workplace Violence and Harassment
An employee can refuse work if they have reason to believe that the current condition of the workplace exposes them to workplace violence.
An employee cannot refuse to work on the grounds of workplace harassment.
An employee cannot refuse to work with someone who has a history of violence, unless the person starts to exhibit violent or threatening behaviour when working with the employee.
Management Responsibilities
Act respectfully at work and while conducting work related activities.
Conduct a risk assessment to identify workplace violence hazards and potential hazards.
Ensure that workers are informed of any actual or potential workplace violence risks, including the nature and extent of the risk.
Inform Joint Health and Safety Committee of the results of the assessment.
Take all reasonable precautions to minimize or eliminate violence related hazards.
Establish procedures for preventing, reporting, investigating, documenting and debriefing workplace violence and harassment incidents.
Ensure that workers are provided with information and instruction that is appropriate for the worker, on the contents of the policy and program
with respect to the prevention of workplace violence and harassment.
Review the efficacy of the workplace violence and harassment prevention program and procedures on a regular basis and in consultation with the Joint Health and Safety Committee.
Take every precaution reasonable if management is aware, or ought reasonably to be aware,
that domestic violence that may occur in the workplace would likely expose a worker to physical injury.
Supervisor Responsibilities
Act respectfully at work and while conducting work related activities.
Promote and encourage the reporting of incidents of violence and harassment.
Maintain records of violence and harassment related complaints, issues, concerns and investigations.
Ensure that workers receive training on the workplace violence and harassment prevention program.
Notify the designated area managers or the human resources department as soon as possible
in the case of observed or suspicious actions that could lead to an incident of violence or harassment in the workplace.
Assist in investigating claims of workplace violence and harassment.
Worker Responsibilities
Do not engage in any improper activity or behaviour at the workplace that might create or constitute a hazard to themselves or to any other person.
Act respectfully at work and while conducting work related activities.
Attend or complete training and education sessions when required.
Immediately report to supervisors, human resources or the compliance line, incidents and/or knowledge of workplace violence or harassment.
Cooperate with investigations.
Conclusion
Through the discussion of handling and preventing workplace violence and harassment, employees should now be familiar with the following topics:
Definitions of workplace violence and harassment
Sources of workplace violence and harassment
Responding to and handling workplace violence and harassment
